FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11 Facility , 1
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - HSHS St. Elizabeth's Hospital. The organization's most recently conducted CHNA was completed for the fiscal year ended 6/30/18. The related implementation strategy that was adopted is for the period July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2021. The information below pertains to the 3rd year cycle of the implementation strategy from the CHNA conducted in the fiscal year 2015. In FY2015, HSHS St. Elizabeth's Hospital conducted a Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA). Primary and secondary data was gathered from multiple sources to assess the hospital's primary service area. Based on the data and the prioritization process, the following priority community health needs were selected: * Wellness/nutrition * Access to care * Heart disease/cerebrovascular disease The FY2015 implementation plan outlined the strategies that the hospital would undertake to address the priority community health needs identified through the CHNA process. Evaluation of the impact of the actions that were taken in response to the hospital's FY2015 CHNA follows. Wellness/Nutrition Outcomes * Partnered with Cosgrove's Kitchen to provide a series of education classes on nutrition and to provided free health screening services. Cosgrove's Soup Kitchen has been an important ministry serving those suffering from the effects of poverty. It is the only facility in the East St. Louis area that offers a free noon meal, six days a week. * Provided support and information to individuals with diabetes to help with self-management. Continued to provide diabetes support programs. Provided health screenings/glucose test and education to the community. Referred and tracked pre-diabetes patients for classes with our partner, the YMCA. Provided the services of a dietitian to organizations free of charge for education about nutrition and healthy eating. * Participated in the East St. Louis Make Health Happen partnership which consists of local community organizations working together to change policy, improve food access, and increase consumption of healthy foods in East St. Louis, Illinois. The Corner Store Initiative increased access to healthy food while building demand in the community through education and promotion of healthy food options. Community partners improved access to nutrition information through healthy cooking demonstrations and an ongoing nutrition-based education series. The hospital participated in community events in East St. Louis including a church health fair, a Corner Store event, and a community center event to support Make Health Happen, and provided blood pressure screenings, healthy recipes and cardiac health education. * Provided nutritional education in senior centers in East St Louis. Under the advice of a hospital dietitian, one local senior center received additional instruction on how to create healthier meals for seniors. Access to Care Outcomes * Communicated information about financial assistance programs to patients who cannot pay for services. Distributed news releases to local media about open enrollment and included information on the hospital's website. Defrayed the cost of an enrollment counselor's services for the county in coordination with the local/regional public health departments. * Contracted with Med-Data, formerly Cardon Outreach, to screen all self-pay patients who presented in inpatient or outpatient. Once screened and eligibility criteria met, patients were assisted with enrollment in Medicaid. In FY2018, more than 4,200 patients were screened and 58% were enrolled in Medicaid. * Assessed further the need for non-emergency medical transportation and identified other organizations for possible collaboration to improve transportation access and/or reduce costs for low income residents. Collaboration completed with current public transportation provider, as appropriate. * Assessed the needs of eligible patients who require medications and services to safely transition patients to an appropriate level of care. Collaborated with other organizations that support the continuum of care for eligible patients and can provide needed services. * Assisted patients with medication, durable medical equipment and transportation. In FY2018, the hospital provided more than $1,800 in cab and bus tickets for patients and more than $1,600 in medications for those in need. The hospital contributed more than $32,000 to defray the cost for patients to be transported by ambulance. * Participated in community resource fairs across the county to address education gaps regarding community members' new health care coverage in collaboration with our community partners. In addition, the hospital focused on cardiovascular and cardiac education, while other agencies provided education on health care coverage and benefits by plan. Routinely, the hospital participates in events and programs in our communities to serve the poor and vulnerable. * Provided flu vaccines to community members who are homeless or clients of Cosgrove's Kitchen. Heart Disease/Cerebrovascular Disease Outcomes * Promoted heart health awareness, education about cardiovascular disease, and healthy eating and lifestyle choices. Hosted community health education during the month of February, nationally recognized as Heart Health Month. Conducted/participated in quarterly community health programs. Met with outside agencies and hospitals and provided cardiac and stroke education. Participated in a HSHS diabetes/cardiac campaign in partnership with Walmart and created a cohort of patients that we can measure and track physical behavioral changes. * In collaboration with our physician partners, the hospital hosted a community resource fair to address education gaps with our patients regarding their new health care coverage. The hospital focused on cardiovascular and cardiac education, while other agencies provided education on health care coverage and benefits by plan. Routinely, the hospital participates in events and programs in our communities to serve the poor and vulnerable. * Provided blood pressure screens and education on cardiovascular risk factors and signs and symptoms of a heart attack to hundreds of community members. Taught hands only CPR in area grade schools. One 5th grade participant recognized that her father was not feeling well and asked if she should call 911 since her mother was not at home. The ambulance arrived and the father had a cardiac arrest on the way to the hospital. Had it not been for the hospital's school-based education and the bravery of this young girl, her father would not be alive. * Collaborated with the YMCA to provide the Lifefit program to meet the complex needs of 15 YMCA under-served families. Sponsored a bike and ride program for community members with the YMCA to promote healthy physical activity. * Continued to provide education classes to our military and civilian partners in the community through courses such as advanced cardiac life support, pediatric advanced life support, and neonatal resuscitation courses. * In addition to the above activities, HSHS St. Elizabeth's continues to engage the community in many other activities that provide support to the poor and under-served. Colleagues mentor students in a variety of disciplines to include a family practice residency program, pharmacy, nursing and multiple ancillary departments. As an outcome of the prioritization process, the following community health needs were also identified and are not being addressed directly by the hospital for the reasons indicated: Mental health and substance abuse was listed as the second health care priority. St. Elizabeth's will continue to partner with local and state agencies to assist. St. Elizabeth's transitioned our mental health resources and expertise to a local community partner. However, the priority health need was identified in the FY18 and will work in collaboration with the county health initiative to address this need. Tobacco Use - The hospital did not take the lead on this issue. It is best addressed through the county health department smoking cessation classes.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11 Facility , 2
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 2 - HSHS St. Elizabeth's Hospital. Poverty- Due to the complexity of this issue the hospital will not take lead. There are several agencies that are addressing this issue. St. Elizabeth's partners with agencies such as East-Side Aligned, Catholic Urban Programs, St. Vincent DePaul, and BEACON ministries, where we can provide support. Violent Crimes- The hospital will not take lead in this because it is not an area of expertise for St. Elizabeth's, however an active partnership exists with the Violence Prevention Center and a positive working relationship exists between St. Elizabeth's and local law enforcement. Sexually Transmitted Diseases-The local health department takes lead for this focus area. Lack of available healthy food and food scarcity. The hospital did not take the lead on this issue. It is addressed by groups including local food pantries, East Side Health District, and East Side Aligned. The hospital supports these efforts by donating healthy food to the local food pantry through our food drives. Maternal and infant health as it relates to infant mortality and teen pregnancy - The hospital has a special care nursery and a pediatrician on staff. In the FY18 CHNA, infant mortality was addressed and the hospital will work in collaboration with the county health initiative to address this need. Lung Cancer - This issue is being addressed in the IPLAN and additionally St. Elizabeth's does offer new technology to screen for lung cancer.

ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital. Presumptive eligibility provides individuals participating in one of the following categories with a 100% write off. These programs are granted by outside organizations based on screening criteria of less than 200% of the FPG. 1. Homelessness 2. Deceased with no estate 3. Mental incapacitation with no one to act on patient's behalf 4. Medicaid eligibility, but not on date of service or for non-covered services 5. Incarceration in a penal institution 6. Enrollment in the following assistance programs for low-income individuals: 6a. Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) 6b. Illinois Housing Development Authority's Rental Housing Support Program 7. Wisconsin Department of Health Services Housing Assistance Program 8. Participation in Women, Infants and Children programs (WIC); 9. Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) eligibility; 10. Illinois Free Lunch and Breakfast Program; 11. Wisconsin Free Lunch Program; 12. Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP); 13. Wisconsin Home Energy Assistance Program (WHEAP); 14. Enrollment in an organized community-based program providing access to medical care that assesses and documents limited low-income financial status as criteria; 15. Receipt of grant assistance for medical services
